snippet: It is difficult to explain why many are drawn to the city, and what many people imagine to be the standard reasons rarely ring true.
abstract: Ginia Bellafante Big City column expresses wonder at what keeps so many people living in New York City with all of its expense, noise and inconveniences; suggests that those who are used to New York might not find sufficient stimulation outside the city. Photo (M)t
lead_paragraph: Nine years ago, when I was introduced to my future husband by a mutual friend, he was working in Nashville, and living 885 miles away, in a town house apartment in Brooklyn. To afford this unusual arrangement, he spent the three or four nights a week that he was in Tennessee at a Motel 6 -- not the Motel 6 closest to his place of employment, but a cheaper branch farther away from the interstate where the sheets, forgetting discussions of thread count, possessed the feel of something made at Union Carbide. During our first date, it did not occur to me to ask him why he chose to live in New York, where he had no familial ties, at such enormous logistical cost. Living here was the goal of all thinking people, and doing so invited complication in nearly every respect; sacrifices were to be made.

headline.main: Exit Ramps Lead Right Back Here
